content.description: The one route at the Rough and Readies which is regularly exposed to high winds. This route may feel more exciting when the winds are blowing through the gap.
content.protection: 3 bolts. The spacing between bolt #1 and #2 is pretty far, but protection can be placed here, either with wires or small cams.
content.location: This is the first line of bolts one sees when approaching the crag.

content.description: Clip the first bolt of Dances with Brangi and head right up over the small roof to the shared anchor.
content.protection: 4 bolts, 2-bolt anchor. It is possible to top rope it by climbing Don't Have a Cow and scrambling from there to the chains Under the Bull shares with Dances with Brangi and Golden Brangus.
content.location: Shared start with Dances with Brangi.

content.description: Some of the guide books show this route as a 5.10b/c, but a hold broke off at the crux making it slightly more difficult. Climb up a thin face and then traverse out left using an awkward rail. At the end of the rail, pull through some strenuous moves to surmount a slight overhang.
content.location: This route stands alone about 75 feet south of the main North End routes.

content.description:
Climb up the line of bolts to the right of Deer Leg (5.8). Warm-up and get your blood flowing in the first half of the climb, step on a small ledge, chalk up, and enter the point of no-return. Climb past the bulge and reach towards the anchors.  

  Warning: make sure you stay within arms length of the bolts. You will throw rocks down if you get off route.
content.location: The long route to the right of Deer Leg (5.8)

content.description: Climb up the crack (30 ft), then follow a thinner crack left to the chains of Windy Gap Overlook.
content.protection: Cams, stoppers.  Use chains for Windy Gap Overlook.
content.location: Overlook Right (aka Trad 6) goes up crack system to the right of Windy Gap Overlook.

content.description: Overlook Left (aka Trad 5) goes up the left side of the face to some square blocks of rock rather than a true overhang. These blocks also provide good cam placements. From there head up and then right towards the chains for Windy Gap Overlook. The climbing is easy but chossy in the lower part, less protectable toward the top.
content.protection: Cams,stoppers.  Use chains for Windy Gap Overlook
content.location: This climb is between the climbs Golden Brangus and Windy Gap Overlook.

content.description: Climb the edges and pockets up the arete and pull the roof with a reachy move.  Trend left to the shared anchor.
Staying left of the bolts keeps the climbing at 5.7, harder if one stays right and follows the arete up. Anchors are slightly right of the route, so cleaning on rappel can be tricky.
content.protection: Well protected with good bolt spacing.
content.location: As you walk in from the north end of the crag, it is the first fully bolted route on a face without an overhang. It is to the left of a cleft/gully in the rock face.

content.description:
A long, fun route with some tendency toward choss at the very top and in some off-route locations. Works with a 60m rope, but only just, so make sure to close your system.  

  There is a skeleton of an actual deer leg up there, hence the name. (The route went by Bambi's Last Leg for a time but reverted to its original name at the request of the originator.)
content.location: It's the bolt line starting up a corner to the left of Don't Have a Cow.

content.description: Climb nice pockets up the slight arete left of the small roof.  A good warm-up route.
content.location: Right of Don't Have a Cow.

content.description:
Climb the crack to the right of Don't Have a Cow. The crux is probably at the bottom, after you leave the large blocks at the beginning of the climb. Some beginners may also have to work at traversing to the left toward the top to be able to reach the chains.  

  It's the easiest route at the Rough and Readies and a fun change of pace. The climbing is okay at best, but for those how can only lead Don't Have a Cow, it does provide another alternative.
content.protection: Top rope off of the anchors to Don't Have a Cow, or if you want to practice trad leading, bring a set of cams and nuts.
content.location: Between Don't Have a Cow and Dances with Brangi.

content.description: The North End has about seven established sport lines including the crags easiest. A couple of the routes share the same anchors making it a good spot for top-roping. This section tends to be the most exposed to winds though, being adjacent to the gap in the hills.
